name: Jenny
comment info: Population growth in North America is decreasing, birth rate is down as well as migration rates. This could have a significant impact on our economy, and could signal a lot about the current status of our country. Less people = less demand, meaning prices could increase. Alongside phenomenon like the Great Resignation, I'd be curious to see how it impacts work and employment rates.

name: Jason
comment info: I have long said that good people should have more kids because there are plenty of bad people having kids. Unfortunately the fear of global warming and over population have discouraged educated people from having kids and getting married. A group of nurses were talking and all of the younger nurses said they would not have kids or maybe one or two. An older nurse, wiser nurse who is now a grandmother said, “I wish I had had more children!” Her family is where her joy comes from. In the 1990’s I took a science class and it was pointed out that with modern farming techniques the earth could easily  support 100 Billion people. There is plenty of land available. Good people, do not let the media scare you, have as many children as you feel you can or want. Society needs as many good people raised in good homes as we can get!!

name: Logan F.
comment info:
I noticed that the natural population increase has been on a decline since 2011. Additionally, I noticed that the immigration population has been decreasing since 2017. In 2021, the U.S. population increased by less than 500,000 people.

I wonder what is causing the natural population increase to decline? What is the prediction on the population change in the upcoming years? 

This relates to me and my community because the population change can affect the economy, infrastructure, etc. As there are less people purchasing items, there is less money circulating which ultimately ends up back in the public’s hands.

This graph depicts how immigration and the natural population change has changed the U.S population. A catchy headline I came up with was “Population Pivots: How Has the U.S. Population Changed Over the Years?”

name: Elizabeth AOSE
comment info: The first thing I noticed was that the population has been on a steady decrease in both categories since around 2016. Before then, the population change had been relatively steady. This makes me wonder what happened around 2016 that caused the overall decrease in population change. The population has also naturally decreased at an extreme amount in the past few years, with it reaching an extreme low in 2021. Immigration has decreased in a similar pattern to the natural population shifts, also reaching a low last year. Covid-19 could've had an effect on the population change in the past 2 years, however it does not explain the decrease in the years prior to 2020. My title for this graph is "Annual Population Change in the US"

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Elizabeth AOSE --

Thank you for your insightful response.

Your headline is "Annual Population Change in the US."  I wonder -- This is a line time series graph.  Would a discrete points for each each have been more appropriate?  Explain your answer, please.

name: Logan AOSE
comment info: In this graph, I notice that both the immigration and natural increase rate have lowered sufficiently from the start of the graph, 2011, to present-day 2021. I also noticed that the natural increase rate dropped at an extremely fast rate in 2020 which I can guess is due to the deaths from COVID-19. Finally, both groups dropped drastically and consistently starting in 2016. I wonder why the drop was so large in 2016 and the causes for it. I know that the Trump administration started the Reforming American Immigration for a Strong Economy (RAISE) Act in August 2017 which reduced levels of legal immigration in the United States by 50% by halving the number of green cards issued. This graph relates to me and my community because my country's policy on immigration affects my family and those I know who are dealing with getting citizenship. A headline that summarizes this graph is "Does Natural Increase or Immigration Affect the U.S Population More?"

name: Caroline C.
comment info: After looking at the graph, I noticed that there was a huge but steady decrease in the number of people immigrating and a natural increase. I also noticed that these rates started falling after 2016 when Trump was elected. Maybe his policies affected this? I wonder what else could have affected this decrease, especially since it became so dramatic starting around 2016. This relates to me and my community because I know many people who are currently immigrating to the US from all countries, including Ukraine at the current moment. A good headline for this graph could be: "Immigration in the Nation"

replies.comment info:
HI, @Caroline C. --

I wonder -- which is decreasing faster -- immigration or natural increase?  Do you think this relationship will continue over the coming decade?

name: KathleenAOSE
comment info: The first thing I notice is that the annual change in population is at an all-time low in ten years. The Birth rate has been steadily going down over the past ten years. This can be contributed to the rising costs of raising a child. Healthcare in the United States is very expensive. Generations now are having trouble financially supporting themselves let alone a child. People are much more likely to be in debt nowadays. People are also getting married much later in life compared to past generations. Immigration has also been steadily decreasing over the past ten years, with the exception of a bump of immigration in 2015-2016. This can be contributed to immigration. This is probably because it has become much harder to obtain a green card in the United States. Policies and processes to get one are becoming much more difficult to get through. Both of these statistics are probably majorly affected by Covid-19. Traveling became much more difficult as many were told to stay in place and some were prohibited from entering the country. I would name this graph, "Annual American Population Rate".

name: Sharon Hessney
comment info:
Thank you for sharing what you notice and wonder in this graph.  

Make sure you read the introductory sentence, the title and the notes below the graph.  They provide information that will help you tease out the story that the graph is telling.  

Also, make those headlines "punchy."  You want to draw the reader into reading the article and examining the graph as well as revealing some of the surprise in the graph.

name: Zachary
comment info: I notice that the change in population started a trend of steady decline around 2016 for immigration and natural birth. Another thing that I noticed was the plummet in population change around 2020 most likely due to Covid-19. name: Brynn
comment info:
What do you notice?
I notice that the graph is showing the population trends in the United States between the years 2011 and 2021. I then notice that the two different color lines show different things with the yellow depicting the trend of natural population increase and the red line which shows the immigration population. From there, you can see that the yellow line is a steady decline over the decade whereas the red line was steadly increasing until about the year 2016 where it began to decrease. This difference shows the trend of natural population increase decreasing whereas the immigration population constantly changing on increases and decreases. 
What do you wonder?
I wonder if any policies were put in place which affected these statistics? Given that President Trump took office in 2016 I am wondering if the change of administration had an affect on the graph? On another topic, I wonder if the new trend in Americans waiting to have children is due to the decrease in the population. 
How does this relate to you and your community?
This relates to me and my community as a citizen of the US constantly being affected by population changes.

name: Colleen D
comment info: This graph depicts population trends in the United States between 2011 and 2021. For this graph, the yellow line, which shows the trend of natural population increase, shows a steady decline over the decade. Whereas the red line, which shows the immigration population, was steadily increasing until 2016 when it began to decrease. I wonder if the population of immigrants switched over from increasing to decreasing due to the beginning of the Trump Administration, which is notorious for having strict immigration laws, in comparison to its previous administration. On the other hand, I wonder if the new trend in Americans waiting to have children is due to the decrease in the population. This affects me and my community because as the population decreases, many social welfare programs, like social security, medicare, etc. will be affected. A title for this graph could be "America's Decreasing Population"

comment info: On the graph the population is decreasing in both immigration and natural increase.

name: Alexa
comment info:
Both of these graphs seemed to have dramatic decreases  after 2019. However, there is a steady decrease in the change in population by immigration and natural increase since 2016. This is probably due in part to several reasons. Immigration policies became very strict with Former President Trump, which limited the amount of immigrants coming into the US. Moreover, the COVID-19 pandemic shut down US borders indefinitely, leaving no one to come in or out. Regarding natural increase, I believe that many young people are not interested in having kids due to financial stability and other things.

I wonder how this change will impact the economy and entities such as social security and retirement in the future. I also wonder how it will impact older generations, who rely on the workforce for their pensions. 

This impacts me and my community because I will be going into the workforce in a few years.

Headline: The population isn't growing, here's why:

replies.comment info:

You’ve’ hit on the head several of the reason for the decline in immigration and natural increase.  See the note below the graph.  From these four components of the population dynamics, what else is going on?

name: Sharon Hessney
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's live moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graph shows the components of total population change – net immigration (international in-migrants minus out-migrants) and natural population change (births minus deaths).  There was a mere 0.1 percent increase in the U.S. population in 2021, the slowest population growth in U.S. history.  

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?"  and “How will this affect you?”  Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in this graph. 

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the article that included this graph and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

Note that you can get a link to your response (and replies made to it) to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

Please visit our archive to see all graphs in this series (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphs).
View our archives that link to all past releases, organized by topic (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTopicIndex), 
graph type (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTypeIndex) and 
Stat Nugget (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsStatNuggetsIndex).  

The next “What’s Going On In This Graph?” will be released by Friday, April 22 with moderation on Wednesday, March 30.  The topic – free speech and cancel culture.  Keep noticing and wondering.

comment info: I notice that both immigration and natural increase had a high change in population during 2015- 2016 but then took a huge drop during 2020 - 2021. I think that was due to Covid-19. name: Ashley
comment info:
